abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the outcome of the project was
            satisfactory, having achieved considerable results in
            defining sector policies, private sector development, and
            environmental issues. The Second Forestry Development
            Project was instrumental in the preparation of, and the
            planning for a national forestry development strategy;
            particularly beneficial, was the private sector development
            component, which promoted communal participation and
            investment activities. Private investments in reforestation
            should progressively attract new enterprises, which could
            eventually cover a variety of forest operations. The report
            provides a number of key lessons, one of the most important
            being that of an integrated approach, essential for a
            successful forestry management. It is also suggested that
            continuity of staff, both the Bank and the Borrower's,
            is critical for an efficient project implementation, for a
            sustained dialogue becomes essential, particularly, if
            controversial issues arise. Discussions with government
            officials and entrepreneurs on issues of conditionalities
            and competitiveness, resulted in appropriate policy changes
            for a successful private sector involvement. High priority
            should be given to forestry maintenance to attain long-term
            benefits and sustainability; should the enterprises become
            involved in forest operations, maintenance requirements
            should be legally specified to ensure those benefits.
